translated: The Questions of King Milinda🔽The Questions of the Wanderer Sakuludāyin
The Chapter about the Monkey
The Questions of Tissa the Embracer

original: “Bhante nāgasena, ‘tacchakassa dve aṅgāni gahetabbānī’ti yaṁ vadesi, katamāni tāni dve aṅgāni gahetabbānī”ti?
analyzed: bhante nāgasena tat śakassa dve aṅgāni gahetabbāni iti yam vadesi katamāni tāni dve aṅgāni gahetabbāni iti
translated: “Revered Nāgasena, when you say two limbs of the Embracer should be taken up, which are these two limbs that should be taken up?”

original: “Yathā, mahārāja, tacchako kāḷasuttaṁ anulometvā rukkhaṁ tacchati;
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja tacchakaḥ kāḷasuttam anulometvā rukkham tacchati
translated: “As, sire, the wood-turner, having straightened the black thread, turns the wood in accordance with it,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, yoginā yogāvacarena jinasāsanamanulomayitvā sīlapathaviyaṁ patiṭṭhahitvā saddhāhatthena paññāvāsiṁ gahetvā kilesā tacchetabbā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja yoginā yogāvacarena jina sāsanam anulomayitvā sīla pathaviyam patiṭṭhahitvā saddhā hatthena paññāvāsim gahetvā kilesā tat śetabbā
translated: even so, sire, the one who is devoted to mental training, having straightened his mind by conformity with the Dispensation of the Conqueror, having established himself on the ground of virtue, having taken the axe of wisdom in the hand of faith, should cut down the defilements.

original: Idaṁ, mahārāja, tacchakassa paṭhamaṁ aṅgaṁ gahetabbaṁ.
analyzed: idam mahā rāja tat śakassa paṭhamam aṅgam
translated: This, sire, is the first limb of the Embracer that should be taken up.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, tacchako phegguṁ apaharitvā sāramādiyati;
analyzed: punar capara mahā rāja tat śako pheggum apaharitvā sāram ādiyati
translated: “And again, sire, the wood-turner, having removed the bark, takes up the heartwood;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, yoginā yogāvacarena sassataṁ ucchedaṁ taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīraṁ
analyzed: evam eva khalu mahā rāja yoginā yogāvacarena ucchedam tam jīvam tam sarīra
translated: even so, sire, the one who is devoted to mental training should avoid eternalism and annihilationism, the soul and the body,

original: aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīraṁ taduttamaṁ aññaduttamaṁ akatamabhabbaṁ apurisakāraṁ abrahmacariyavāsaṁ
analyzed: aññam jīvam aññam sarīram tad uttamam aññat uttamam a katama bhabbam a purisakāram a brahmacariya vāsa
translated: another and this, the highest and the highest beyond, the unmade and the unmade beyond, the not-human-made and the not-human-made beyond, the not-lived-as-Brahma-life and the not-lived-as-Brahma-life beyond,

original: sattavināsaṁ navasattapātubhāvaṁ saṅkhārasassatabhāvaṁ yo karoti, so paṭisaṁvedeti,
analyzed: satta vināsam nava satta pātubhāvam saṅkhāra sassata bhāvam yaḥ karoti so paṭisavedeti
translated: He who makes the seven destructions and the appearance of the new seven worlds, the eternalism of formations, he experiences.

original: añño karoti, añño paṭisaṁvedeti, kammaphaladassanā ca kiriyaphaladiṭṭhi ca iti evarūpāni
analyzed: aññaḥ karoti aññaḥ paṭisavedeti kamma phala dassanā ca kiriya phala diṭṭhi ca iti evarūpāni
translated: One does the action, another experiences the result. The view of the result of action and the view of the result of what is done.🔽And other such views as these,

original: ceva aññāni ca vivādapathāni apanetvā saṅkhārānaṁ sabhāvaṁ paramasuññataṁ nirīhanijjīvataṁ
analyzed: ca iva aññāni ca vivāda pathāni apanetvā saṅkhārānam sabhāvam parama suññatam
translated: and other paths of dispute, should be set aside. The own-nature of formations, the highest emptiness, the absence of striving and living,
the uttermost emptiness, should be accepted.

original: Idaṁ, mahārāja, tacchakassa dutiyaṁ aṅgaṁ gahetabbaṁ.
analyzed: idam mahā rāja tat śakassa dutiyam aṅgam
translated: This, great king, is the second quality of the sincere man that should be adopted.

analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavatā devātidevena sutta nipāte
translated: And this was said, great king, by the Blessed One, the God above Gods, in the Sutta Nipāta:🔽‘Destroy the chaff,
remove the husk,
and then drive out the straw,
the non-ascetic who is proud of being an ascetic.
Having destroyed the wicked,
the wicked conduct and behaviour,
the pure should live together with the pure,
the one who is pure should be mindful.
Then, united and alert,
they will make an end to suffering.’
The tenth chapter, on the question of the qualities of the sincere man.
The sixth section, on the monkey.
The summary:
Monkey, boy, crab,
forest, tree, fifth;
Cloud, gem, hunter,
fisherman, saw, and spear.
